mapped_songs.post_title: 100 Greatest Driving Songs | Dad Rock | Songs For The Car 2025 | Road Trip Music
mapped_songs.comment_text: My wife passed away 7 years ago from cancer. This was her favorite song. One night, about 10 years ago, we went to a karaoke night at a local bar. I sang...like I always do...or did...doing Billy Joel or Elton John. The people there seemed to like it. My wife...after several vodka and tonics...decides to do this song. I'd heard her sing at home before. So i was very much afraid. From the very first words...my jaw dropped!! I couldn't believe what I was hearing!!  She nailed it...and then some!  I'll never forget it. The crowd went nuts...as did I. Every time I hear this song ...I think of her. And how i know it was never about me. Thanks for posting.
mapped_songs.ananki_reasoning: This is a bittersweet memory of the commenter's late wife performing her favorite song at karaoke about 10 years ago, shortly before she passed away from cancer 7 years ago. The story captures a beautiful, unexpected moment of joy and discovery (hearing his wife sing beautifully for the first time in public), but it's framed through the lens of grief and loss. The song itself becomes a vessel for nostalgic sadness - a cherished memory of a loved one who is gone. While the original song 'You're So Vain' is a confident, assertive breakup anthem, the emotional context here transforms it into something deeply personal and melancholic, tied to remembrance and longing for a deceased spouse.
